Award.AwardTitle: Higher Innovation for Students in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HIS in HSIs)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This workshop project is designed to bring together dedicated faculty members in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) from across the USA to share and acquire up-to-date knowledge in a conference format about the most effective strategies for improving retention and graduation rates of Hispanic students majoring in STEM disciplines. Attending will be faculty instructors and administrators from an equal number of 2-year and 4-year HSI institutions. The focus is on successful approaches that have worked for Hispanic students. The conference is covering emerging topics of particular interest to HSIs, including data about outcomes of new approaches that is being disseminated for the first time. The workshop will focus in particular on around high-context educational activities (e.g. internships, co-ops, and research experiences with faculty members as mentors) that students from Hispanic origins find particularly empowering and motivating.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Higher Innovation for Students in Hispanic Serving Institutions (HIS in HSIs) conference (held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, on Thursday and Friday 9/10/2015 - 9/11/2015) was a gathering of professors and administrators from several US States (Arizona, Texas, California, and New Mexico) to discuss best educational practices for student success in universities and community colleges, especially institutions with a high percentage of minority students. There were several speakers presenting (e.g. Dr Susan Castillo and Prof. Cordelia Ontiveros from Project Lead the Way; Professor Ricardo Jacquez from California State University Chico; Professor Roberto Ibarra from the University of New Mexico), ones who are involved in national efforts and programs to promote STEM education and especially as pertaining to minority students. Five different presentations on educational best-practices were provided. The total number of conference attendees, including all presenters, were 35. The conference was successful and participants attended presentations and workshops that helped prepare them for better student success at their institutions. Participants went away equipped with more ideas which could be implemented and adapted at their institution. The general impression of the attendees was that such conferences provide important knowledge to be spread across the Nation for all institutions to benefit from them.


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Tariq A Khraishi
